G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Taylor, respectfully petitions this Honorable Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 to modify the custody and parenting time order entered on June 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Taylor, respectfully petitions this Honorable Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 to modify the custody and parenting time order entered on June 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: Massachusetts is also the home state of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 209B, § 2.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A parent’s failure to support a child’s education or ensure attendance at school constitutes grounds for modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether there was a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody when the mother sought to relocate, and it ultimately reverses the change of custody. It does not discuss a parent’s failure to support a child’s education or ensure school attendance as a ground for modification, nor does it make any holding tying educational neglect or truancy to modification standards. The case therefore does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: A parent’s failure to support a child’s education or ensure attendance at school constitutes grounds for modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas concerns custody, joint vs. sole physical custody, and removal of children from the Commonwealth under the “real advantage” standard. It does not address parental failure to support a child’s education or ensure school attendance, nor does it treat such failure as grounds for modification of any prior order. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a parent’s failure in those respects constitutes grounds for modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.proposition: The best interests of the child are paramount in custody determinations.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30 the phrase “upon cause shown” means that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and repeatedly frames the court’s task in terms of determining and prioritizing the children’s best interests. The court affirms the lower court’s decision on the ground that the judge properly considered and applied the best interests standard in resolving the relocation/custody dispute. This squarely supports the proposition that in custody-related determinations (here, relocation), the child’s best interests are paramount.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… [a child] shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent’s inability to meet the child’s educational needs demonstrates a failure to act in the child’s best interest.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the general Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ custody standard and discusses factors like stability, willingness to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent, and avoidance of alienation. It does not state or imply that an inability to meet a child’s *educational* needs, specifically, constitutes a failure to act in the child’s best interest, nor does it frame any holding around educational needs. The proposition therefore overstates and mischaracterizes what this case decides.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’… The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child's present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent's home is more stable in terms of a parent's work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 597.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent’s inability to meet the child’s educational needs demonstrates a failure to act in the child’s best interest.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 597.support_reasoning: The opinion does not state or apply any rule that a parent’s inability to meet a child’s educational needs demonstrates a failure to act in the child’s best interests. Education is mentioned only factually (that the child is doing well in school and the father is attentive), and the legal analysis and holding focus on domestic violence and the need for explicit findings about its impact in custody determinations. The case therefore does not establish or affirm the broader, consistent rule about educational needs claimed in the proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 597.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers. Finally, the Probate Court judge noted that the father, who had been a heavy drinker, had not used alcohol since 1985 and attends weekly sessions of Alcoholics Anonymous. The court also mandated that both parents should remain in therapy.”
